author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: ‘We Just Want Him to Leave’: Protests Persist Against Belarus’s Leader
description: Although no arrests or clashes were reported on Sunday, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko told a rally of supporters this weekend that protesters had until Monday to calm down.
content: MINSK, Belarus — One day after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus promised to crush with an iron fist the protests that have broken out since his re-election this month, tens of thousands of people took to the streets of the capital, Minsk, on Sunday to show their determination to force him out of office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: After Another Week of Setbacks, Trump Looks to Change the Story Line
description: The president heads into the Republican National Convention after a string of bad news, including the arrest of a former top aide and a damning reminder of Russia’s interference in the last election.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump’s strategists mapped out their plans for the critical week leading to the Republican National Convention that would nominate him for a second term, the schedule somehow did not include a sensational arrest on a Chinese billionaire’s yacht.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Christchurch Massacre Sentencing: What to Expect
description: Brenton Tarrant pleaded guilty in March after murdering 51 people and wounding 40 at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand. But the final phase of the case presents a series of challenges.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Brenton Tarrant killed 51 people and wounded 40 more at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, last year, an act of hate and terrorism unlike anything the remote island country had ever seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: The Economic Recovery That Isn’t
description: Don’t believe the story that Trump will tell at the Republican convention.
content: As Republicans take the virtual stage for their convention this week, expect to hear much chest pounding about how great the economy has been under Donald Trump’s leadership and how fast it is coming back from the virus-induced shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Billions in Hospital Virus Aid Rested on Compliance With Private Vendor
description: The Department of Health and Human Services told hospitals in April that reporting to the vendor, TeleTracking Technologies, was a “prerequisite to payment.”
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration tied billions of dollars in badly needed coronavirus medical funding this spring to hospitals’ cooperation with a private vendor collecting data for a new Covid-19 database that bypassed the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Battle With the Popular TikTok App
description: One reader suggests “it’s personal, not business.” Another finds community with other teens on the Chinese app.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Woman Waiting to Get On Told Me That My Shoe Was Untied’
description: Getting off the M104, a first Halloween in Manhattan and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: In Ohio, a Father and Stepdaughter Show the Political Shifts in the Trump Era
description: He’s a union worker and former Democrat now solidly behind President Trump. She’s a onetime Republican now worried about her sons growing up in the Trump era. Family get-togethers can be difficult.
content: NEWTON FALLS, Ohio — An hour after Kamala Harris was announced as Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate last week, Dan Moore sat in his living room watching the Fox News coverage of her selection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Henry Fountain
title: New Conditions on Alaskan Mine Could Delay Vast Project That Donald Trump Jr. Opposes
description: The Army Corps of Engineers will impose new mitigation conditions on the developers of the proposed Pebble Mine, potentially pushing approval past the election.
content: WASHINGTON — The Army Corps of Engineers will impose new demands for mitigating environmental damage from a vast proposed copper and gold mine in Alaska, potentially delaying approvals for the project beyond the presidential election, three people familiar with the Corps’s plans said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: 10 Under-the-Radar Movies for Offbeat Times
description: A guide to streaming films you may not have considered in your quest to entertain yourself at home.
content: The strangest summer in recent memory draws to a close with the multiplexes again reopening — to those who want to take the risk of spending two hours indoors laughing and eating alongside strangers. The rest of us will remain in front of our televisions and laptops, facing down a seemingly dwindling number of streaming options. But not to worry; we’ve again combed through the back stacks of your virtual movie library to offer up a few titles that might have escaped your notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Mercedes Barcha, Gabriel García Márquez’s Wife and Muse, Dies at 87
description: For nearly 60 years, she was the Nobel Prize-winning novelist’s companion and inspiration, his sharp-witted foil and his chief of staff.
content: Mercedes Barcha, the widow, muse and gatekeeper of the Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez, who played a crucial role in the publication of his breakthrough novel, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” died on Aug. 15 at her home in Mexico City. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Conservatives Pick a Leader to Rival Scandal-Scarred Trudeau
description: The party, which has struggled to respond to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s liberal platform and personal popularity, hopes the new leader, Erin O’Toole, can change that.
content: When the four contenders to lead Canada’s Conservative Party gathered virtually in June for an English-language debate, one subject dominated their conversation: the many ways they believed Prime Minister Justin Trudeau had failed Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian F. Schaffner, Jesse H. Rhodes and Raymond J. La Raja
title: Why Trump Never Stops Talking About ‘Our Suburbs’
description: Political polarization along racial lines is worst in small towns and suburbs, where more than half of African-Americans live.
content: In the wake of the police killings of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, cities and towns across the nation erupted in mass protests against police violence and systemic racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Twitter Flags Trump Tweet for Dissuading Voting
description: The social media service hid the president’s post about ballot drop boxes, saying it violated Twitter’s election integrity rules.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twitter hid one of President Trump’s tweets behind a notice warning users that the message violated company rules against dissuading people from voting. Mr. Trump posted the tweet, which said that ballot drop boxes were not being sanitized to prevent the coronavirus and could be used for fraud, about five hours before Twitter took action on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: With ‘Unhinged,’ Hollywood Cautiously Returns to Movie Theaters
description: The Russell Crowe thriller brought in $4 million domestically — a figure that would normally disappoint but, given the pandemic, is seen as a success.
content: This weekend Hollywood took a toe dip back into theaters with the wide release of “Unhinged,” the Russell Crowe thriller that opened Friday in 1,823 locations across the country, including drive-ins in California and large cineplexes in San Antonio, Tex., Oklahoma City and Orlando.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Meacham
title: The South’s Fight for White Supremacy
description: Immediately after the Civil War ended, the South began a campaign to deny the true meaning of the conflict.
content: He had tried, and failed, once before. In 1859, the Virginian Edward Alfred Pollard, a journalist and Southern partisan, had published a defense of slavery, “Black Diamonds Gathered in the Darkey Homes of the South.” Then came the election of Abraham Lincoln, the Civil War, the Emancipation Proclamation and the 13th Amendment, which abolished the system of slavery Pollard had hoped to preserve. After the Confederate surrender at Appomattox in April 1865, he turned to a new project, publishing, in 1866, a book titled “The Lost Cause: A New Southern History of the War of the Confederates.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Sun Narin
title: Threatened by Facebook Disinformation, a Monk Flees Cambodia
description: A smear campaign linked to the Cambodian government went viral on the social media platform, sending an activist Buddhist cleric into exile to protect himself.
content: BANGKOK — In just four days, the reputation of a Buddhist monk who had spent decades fighting for the human rights of Cambodians was destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: Takuma Sato Wins His Second Indy 500
description: The Japanese driver, who also won in 2017, held off Scott Dixon of New Zealand over the final 20 laps to win after a front-row start.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — On the verge of running out of fuel, Takuma Sato was instead able to hold on to win the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday for the second time in his career, this one over a frustrated Scott Dixon as the 2020 race finished under caution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corporate America Agrees Black Lives Matter. What Comes Next?
description: In a recent DealBook forum, Times journalists took stock of how much the country’s most powerful companies are backing up statements against systemic racism.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Outdoor Dining Is a Hit, but Restaurants Face ‘Apocalyptic’ Times
description: Nearly 10,000 restaurants have set up outdoor seating in New York City. They are struggling to stay alive until indoor dining returns.
content: A dozen people were waiting in line when Imani in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, opened for brunch on a recent Saturday morning. That evening, diners packed the sidewalk tables at Anton’s, a cafe and wine bar in Greenwich Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: In China, Where the Pandemic Began, Life Is Starting to Look … Normal
description: Markets, bars and restaurants are crowded again. Local virus transmissions are near zero. But some worry that people are letting their guard down too soon.
content: In Shanghai, restaurants and bars in many neighborhoods are teeming with crowds. In Beijing, thousands of students are heading back to campus for the fall semester. In Wuhan, where the coronavirus emerged eight months ago, water parks and night markets are packed elbow to elbow, buzzing like before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Just in Time for the Election: An Asteroid?
description: The object has a slender chance of hitting Earth — but even if it does, it’s too small to do any damage, astronomers say.
content: According to NASA and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, about the only thing we don’t have to worry about on the eve of the U.S. elections on Nov. 3 is being blasted to interplanetary bits by a rogue asteroid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Dry Thunderstorms Could Accelerate the California Wildfires
description: Lightning, erratic winds and no rain would make it even tougher for firefighters to battle some of the largest blazes in state history.
content: With wildfires burning almost one million acres of California, storms may sound like needed relief. But the dry thunderstorms projected to arrive as early as Sunday morning are the worst of both worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: 2 Dead and 2 Missing After Pipeline Explosion in Corpus Christi
description: Six people were injured, officials said, including some who were taken to hospitals to be treated for burns.
content: A submerged pipeline that exploded and a fire on board a dredging vessel on Friday left two crew members dead and two others missing in Corpus Christi, Texas, the U.S. Coast Guard said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Kate Kelly
title: Electric Vehicle Makers Find a Back Door to Wall Street
description: Special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, are helping them and other fledgling companies raise money and gain coveted stock listings.
content: Steve Burns pulled together several pieces of a business venture over the last year: His company, Lordstown Motors, designed an electric pickup truck, acquired a plant and machinery from General Motors, and racked up thousands of orders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Dr. Alyce Gullattee, Expert on Substance Abuse, Dies at 91
description: Dr. Gullattee, who died of the coronavirus, taught at Howard University and served on White House committees for Presidents Nixon, Ford and Carter.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Ryan
title: Review: ‘The Vow’ Follows Nxivm Down Dark, Damaging Paths
description: The HBO documentary series delves into the toxic group that has been widely described as a “sex cult.” But that only scratches the surface.
content: Everyone involved in the nine-part documentary series “The Vow,” which chronicles the twisted saga of Nxivm, seems pretty media savvy. They know how easily complicated stories can get condensed into the shorthand of headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Black Artists Find Ways to Make Their Voices Heard in Portland
description: The burst of creativity that has swept through town in recent weeks could provide a road map for other cities confronting historical racism.
content: Over the years, Bobby Fouther has watched the historic center of African-American life in Portland bloom, shrink and expand again. The 69-year-old artist was born into a creative family from the neighborhood of Albina, which he remembers filled with jazz music and beauty. “Black artists were thriving here in the 1950s,” he recalled. “My parents had turned our grandfather’s garage into a miniature theater, where my stepfather and his friends would perform late into the night.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: For the R.N.C., a convention with some in-person elements is a priority.
description: The Republican convention that is unfolding as delegates gather in Charlotte this weekend is nothing like anyone envisioned more than two years ago, when the city was selected to host a raucous gathering to renominate President Trump. There were going to be parties and after-parties, and the city expected $200 million of economic impact.
content: The Republican convention that is unfolding as delegates gather in Charlotte this weekend is nothing like anyone envisioned more than two years ago, when the city was selected to host a raucous gathering to renominate President Trump. There were going to be parties and after-parties, and the city expected $200 million of economic impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Smashed Windows on Subway Cars Have Cost the M.T.A. $300,000
description: The vandalism, which harkens back to a period of economic hardship in New York City, comes at a time when the transit agency is facing a staggering financial crisis.
content: Transportation officials in New York City first began seeing broken windows on subway cars, mostly on the 2, 3 and 7 lines, in April. On one day in mid-July, nearly 50 windows across three 7 trains were smashed. Then this week, the problem seemed to have intensified again: about 60 windows on several 7 trains were found shattered with what officials said was a “blunt instrument.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Christina Morales
title: Louisiana Braces As Hurricane Marco Approaches With a Stronger Storm Right Behind It
description: The “one-two punch” of hurricanes has created a heightened sense of alarm along the Gulf Coast. Officials warned residents they might have to shelter in place for as long as 72 hours.
content: ATLANTA — As Hurricane Marco barreled toward Louisiana as a Category 1 storm, officials urged residents on Sunday to seek higher ground and make sure they were stocked up on food and supplies. They were repeating a message that is part of a predictable summer routine on the Gulf Coast as hurricane season reaches its climax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia, Expecting Plaudits for Vaccine, Is Miffed by Its Cool Reception
description: Russian officials and scientists dismiss warnings about safety as Western jealousy and sour grapes. But only 24 percent of Russian doctors would take the vaccine, one survey shows.
content: MOSCOW — It was with great fanfare that President Vladimir V. Putin and other officials announced this month that a billion doses of a Russian vaccine for the new coronavirus would soon be rolled out, supposedly putting an end to the worst pandemic in a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Detroit Firefighter Dies Trying to Save Girls From Drowning
description: Sgt. Sivad Johnson, 49, a 26-year veteran of the Detroit Fire Department, dived in to rescue the girls, who were later safely brought ashore.
content: The body of a Detroit firefighter was recovered from the Detroit River on Saturday, a day after he dived into the water to save three young girls from drowning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Crocs and Irukandji: A World Away From the Coronavirus Pandemic. Almost.
description: In Tropical Far North Queensland, the coronavirus pandemic can seem worlds away, until the veneer of normality crumbles.
content: For the past few weeks, I have worried more about being stung by a deadly Irukandji jellyfish or attacked by a crocodile, rather than contracting the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Neymar Finally Grows Up
description: Paris St.-Germain brought in the Brazilian forward to win games like Sunday’s Champions League final. The key to achieving his goal, and the club’s, may be realizing he doesn’t have to do it alone.
content: Neymar was as good as his word. As he stepped off Paris St.-Germain’s bus a couple of hours before his team’s Champions League quarterfinal against Atalanta, all the pieces were in place. He had his sunglasses perched on his head. He had a speaker blaring “Hoje É Rave,” by the Brazilian D.J.s Bárbara Labres and MC WM. And, as he had promised, he had his hair cut into a mohawk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Bayern Munich Wins Champions League, a Victory for Tradition and Team
description: Kingsley Coman’s second-half goal gave the German champions a 1-0 victory over Paris St.-Germain, and their sixth title in European soccer’s top club competition.
content: In that moment of elation, the cameras hunted for despair. They found it in the slight, forlorn shape of Neymar, sitting on Paris St.-Germain’s bench, a perfect picture of heartbreak. Neymar, with tears in his eyes. Neymar, staring into the middle distance. Neymar, with his head in his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Speech for Trump About Covid-19 (if Only He Would Give It)
description: A reader crafts a speech for the president urging Americans to put aside differences and follow public health advice. Also: Children at risk of abuse; faster Covid test results; musical distraction.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Rory Smith
title: Champions League Final: What You Need to Know About P.S.G. vs. Bayern Munich
description: P.S.G., the perennial French champion, will face Bayern Munich, Germany’s most decorated club, on Sunday.
content: Follow here for live updates from the Champions League final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Steve Eder and David Enrich
title: Virgin Islands Will Subpoena Billionaire Investor in Epstein Case
description: The territory’s attorney general wants to know more about Leon Black’s dealings with Jeffrey Epstein, who died while facing sex-trafficking charges.
content: Officials in the U.S. Virgin Islands want the billionaire investor Leon Black, one of the most powerful men on Wall Street, to hand over information about his decades-long business ties to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: In Portland, a Prosecutor Must Decide: Which Protesters Should Go to Jail?
description: Portland’s new district attorney has refused to prosecute hundreds of low-level offenses tied to recent demonstrations against systemic racism and police brutality.
content: Just weeks after President Trump’s administration agreed to pull back federal officers from demonstrations in Portland, Ore., where his attempt at a high-profile crackdown backfired, the fate of the city’s protests now rests to a large extent with an altogether different leader: A brand-new, 39-year-old district attorney whose approach to enforcing the law is as contested as the demonstrations themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Doctors Enter College Football’s Politics, but Maybe Just for Show
description: Universities have had mixed messages, competing agendas and a lack of transparency as they consider whether to hold college football in the fall, with billions of dollars at stake.
content: As Justin Fields, the star quarterback at Ohio State, was gathering more than 300,000 electronic signatures to beseech Big Ten university presidents to reverse their decision to postpone football this fall, he was applauded by his coach, Ryan Day, who in turn was being hailed by his athletic director, Gene Smith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Christchurch massacre sentencing, China, TikTok: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The sentencing hearing for Brenton Tarrant, the Australian former fitness instructor who killed 51 people and wounded 40 last year at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, will begin on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Sophia Popov, Ranked 304th, Wins Women’s British Open
description: It was the German golfer’s first major championship, and the prize, $675,000, was more than six times her career earnings before Sunday.
content: TROON, Scotland — Sophia Popov marked her ball a few inches from the hole on the 18th green, pulled the brim of her cap over her face and began to cry in the arms of her caddie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: The Incestuous Relationship Between Donald Trump and Fox News
description: In his new book, “Hoax,” Brian Stelter examines Fox’s role as a White House propaganda organ masquerading as conservative journalism.
content: HOAXDonald Trump, Fox News and the Dangerous Distortion of TruthBy Brian Stelter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Vague allegations against Alex Morse offer a case study in how progressives navigate issues of sex and power.
description: On Aug. 7, the student newspaper at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst reported that the state chapter of the College Democrats had disinvited Alex Morse, a congressional candidate and former guest lecturer at the university, from its future events, claiming “numerous incidents” of unwanted and inappropriate advances toward students.
content: On Aug. 7, the student newspaper at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst reported that the state chapter of the College Democrats had disinvited Alex Morse, a congressional candidate and former guest lecturer at the university, from its future events, claiming “numerous incidents” of unwanted and inappropriate advances toward students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Put those tomatoes to work: in greens and beans on toast, in gazpacho, or just a simple caprese.
content: One of my favorite things to cook right now is pan con tomate, and it doesn’t involve much cooking at all: Grate a tomato on a box grater, season it generously with olive oil, salt and pepper (and nice vinegar if the tomato tastes a bit flat), then use it to dip and dress a thick piece of toast, rubbed with garlic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Authorizes Plasma Treatment for Virus, but the Big Prize for the White House Is a Vaccine
description: The fast-tracking could come before Phase 3 trials are complete, raising concerns. Life in China, where the pandemic began, is returning to normal.
content: Trump administration officials met with congressional leaders last month and told them they would probably give emergency approval to a coronavirus vaccine before the end of Phase 3 clinical trials in the United States, perhaps as early as late September, according to two people briefed on the discussion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Sweatpants Forever’
description: Much of the fashion industry has buckled under the weight of the coronavirus — it appears to have sped up the inevitable.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Dan Budnik, Who Photographed History, Is Dead at 87
description: His assignments for leading magazines took him to pivotal events of the civil rights era. He was also known for his photographs of artists.
content: Dan Budnik, who in a long career as a photographer captured abiding images of 1950s artists at work, key events of the civil rights movement, the Hudson River restoration effort, Native Americans in the Southwest and more, died on Aug. 14 at an assisted living residence in Tucson, Ariz. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Smeyne, Laylah Amatullah Barrayn, Christopher Lee and Ashley Gilbertson
title: What the First Virtual Convention Looked Like Across America
description: This is democracy, at a social distance.
content: For the first time in the history of our democracy, the Democratic National Convention was not a gathering in person for delegates to debate their chosen primary candidates, hammer out a platform, and ultimately nominate their candidates for America’s top officers. As opposed to a traditional crowded convention hall spectacle, delegates and candidates gathered online this year. From Zoom rooms, Google hangouts and other online spaces they gathered remotely from homes across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Vow’ and ‘The August Virgin’
description: An HBO documentary series delves into the downfall of Nxivm. And Itsaso Arana stars in a languid summer film set in Madrid.
content: THE VOW 10 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO Max. In 2019, Keith Raniere, the leader of the self-improvement group known as Nxivm, was convicted on charges of racketeering and sex trafficking, his trial exposing the shadowy organization’s inner workings. The group had attracted high-profile members — including the “Smallville” actress Allison Mack and the heiress Clare Bronfman — and in 2017, troubling reports of coercion, blackmail and abuse began to surface. This nine-part documentary series examines the disturbing practices that made headlines, but it also delves deeper into the organization to understand why people joined in the first place. Through interviews with former members, the filmmakers Jehane Noujaim and Karim Amer explore the fall of the organization and the emotional toll that it took on those hoping it could help them lead a better life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: End of a Lunch Hour
description: David Alfred Bywaters needs cheering up.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — I am not a nosy person by nature, but if I didn’t know better, I would say that the constructor David Alfred Bywaters is feeling down (sorry).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Shouting Turns to Violence in Portland as Dueling Protests Converge
description: Paintballs and pepper spray filled the air during a confrontation in Oregon between a pro-police rally and Black Lives Matter supporters.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Right-wing and left-wing groups clashed in front of the U.S. courthouse in Portland, Ore., on Saturday, weeks after federal agents pulled back from the site of protests that have gripped part of the city’s downtown for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Hooks and Jocelyn Simonson
title: The Power of Community Bail Funds
description: They help keep people’s lives from being ruined by exorbitant bail. Efforts to thwart these funds are the true public safety threats.
content: At least 10,000 protesters and ordinary people have been freed from jail and immigrant detention facilities after months of uprisings in which millions of dollars have been donated to nearly 80 community bail funds nationwide. But the backlash has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Alex Morse Was Accused, Condemned and Then Vindicated. Will His Experience Change Anything?
description: Vague allegations against the Massachusetts congressional candidate offer a case study in how progressives navigate issues of sex and power in politics when judgment is often swift and unforgiving.
content: Political careers usually don’t survive allegations like these. And for about a week, it seemed as if Alex Morse’s might not either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: President’s Sister Describes Trump as Liar With ‘No Principles’ in Recordings
description: In a series of recordings published by The Washington Post, Maryanne Trump Barry can be heard disparaging her brother’s performance as president.
content: WASHINGTON — Maryanne Trump Barry, President Trump’s older sister and a former federal judge, described him as a liar who has “no principles” in a series of audio recordings made by her niece, Mary L. Trump, in 2018 and 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Annie Karni
title: Republicans Rush to Finalize Convention (‘Apprentice’ Producers Are Helping)
description: The party is promising a more traditional in-person spectacle with President Trump speaking every night. Coming into this weekend, major TV networks had only a foggy idea of what to expect.
content: Democrats set a high bar last week for the pandemic-era political convention, dispensing with cheering crowds in favor of a virtual pageant that encompassed passionate speeches, a charming cross-country roll call vote, vignettes from an Oscar-winning filmmaker and a low-fi fireworks display above a parking lot. A few hiccups aside, even jaded network executives conceded the party mostly pulled it off.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In a Restaurant City, an Alfresco Bid to Survive
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 23, 2020.
content: “If it’s not safe to open, I understand that — I’m a team player. But you got to do something about my rent, my payroll. You got to answer these questions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Steve Bannon Charged With Fraud
description: The stock market hit a record high, unemployment claims rose again, and the office might not be dead after all.
content: Good morning! I’ve been craving a real office lately — for the free air conditioning, mostly, but also the sense of purpose it offers. You may not agree, but Amazon is betting that I’m not alone, and expanding its office spaces in several cities. Here’s what else you need to know in business and tech for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Lee Brewer and Manny Fernandez
title: In Tulsa, Where Race Relations Are Raw, a White Mayor Feels the Heat
description: Mayor G.T. Bynum finds himself on the defensive over the presidential campaign, the coronavirus pandemic and the uproar over police abuse.
content: On what has become a solemn date in Tulsa, a group of Black leaders met with Mayor G.T. Bynum on the first of June. It was the 99th anniversary of one of the deadliest race riots in American history, when a Black neighborhood in the city was destroyed by a white mob in 1921.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 23, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 23, 2020.
content: An article this weekend on Page 8 about a ballet school in Lagos, Nigeria, misidentifies a ballet school in Birmingham, England. It is the Elmhurst Ballet School of Birmingham Royal Ballet, not of Birmingham Royal Academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Fatima Faizi and Najim Rahim
title: With Delay in Afghan Peace Talks, a Creeping Sense of ‘Siege’ Around Kabul
description: Instead of mass-casualty attacks, the Taliban are carrying out targeted assaults in the capital and neighboring districts. The country’s security forces seem unable to control them.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Mornings in the city begin with “sticky bombs,” explosives slapped onto vehicles that go up in flames. With night comes the dread of hit-and-run assassinations in the nearby suburbs — government employees shot dead by motorcycle-riding insurgents who roam free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Hiroko Masuike
title: California Fires, Republicans, Pasta Sauce: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: For a Music Critic, a Vacation That’s All Too Quiet
description: With performances silenced by the coronavirus, our chief classical music critic has been left wishing for more sound, not less.
content: Typically, the end of August through Labor Day is an ideal time for me to take a two-week vacation. Classical music tends to take that time off, too. After a jam-packed concert season and a slew of summer festivals, everything seems to stop for a bit before the ramp-up to fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: In California’s Wine Country, a Familiar Threat of Smoke and Flame
description: Wildfires are raging across Northern California, including in Napa and Sonoma Counties, but locals are used to the danger.
content: NAPA, Calif. — If it were not for the thick blanket of smoke hanging low in the cloudy afternoon sky, there would be no way to tell that anything was amiss in downtown Napa on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: To Test Spread of Coronavirus, These Scientists Put on a Concert
description: In Germany, volunteers gathered in an arena for an experiment that could help create safety measures for live events around the world.
content: LEIPZIG, Germany — The German pop singer Tim Bendzko was trying his best to energize the crowd at Quarterback Immobilien Arena here on Saturday morning. Flanked by band members and backup singers, he bounced across a stage at the indoor concert and sports venue, thrusting his microphone toward about 1,400 tightly packed audience members, prompting them to sing along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Bloch
title: Map: Tracking Tropical Storms Laura and Marco
description: Tracking two tropical storms that could make landfall on the Gulf Coast this week.
content: Tracking two tropical storms that could make landfall on the Gulf Coast this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How is the Coronavirus Affecting Low-Income Families? Share Your Story.
description: The New York Times would like to learn more about how households making less than $30,000 or so are making ends meet and what impact the pandemic is having on them.
content: The New York Times would like to learn more about how households making less than $30,000 or so are making ends meet and what impact the pandemic is having on them.

title: A Film Pantheon That Omits Black Directors
description: Just six of more than 1,000 titles in the prestigious Criterion Collection are by African-American directors. Why?
content: Just six of more than 1,000 titles in the prestigious Criterion Collection are by African-American directors. Why?
